number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 20, 2014
Early Access Review
								A physics-based sandbox where you manipulate objects  to your liking. Play Poker, Backgammon, Checkers, Chess, and a handful of other games by default! Download mods for the game to play your favorite card and board games including: Pokemon Trading Card Game, Cards Against Humanity, Risk, Munchkin, Clue, etc.This game is best when played with friends, but is still fun when playing with strangers due to the built-in voice communication which actually sounds pretty good.Grow and shrink objects to your heart's content, knock everything over with a giant hydra that takes up the whole table! Lost a hand at Texas Hold Em'? Flip the table. Win a hand at Texas Hold Em'? Flip the table. Someone flip the table? Flip the table. Trolling in this game is as fun as playing the actual game itself. The possibilities are endless with the new Steam Workshop integration. There will be even more games added, and a bunch of awesome looking objects to be released in time!I highly recommend this game.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2016
												Simulator games have frequently been a bit of a joke to a lot of people.  There's a reason why Goat Simulator is so popular after all, so much so that certain devs are starting to look at the name "Simulator" with a bit of hesitation.  On the surface, a few people might think that Tabletop Simulator is a bit of a joke as well due to some of the things it offers(Flipping the table, zero gravity mode, etc), but what it offers honestly makes it worth the price and shows that it's more than just a silly little thing.Graphics:Tabletop Simulator's graphics, as a whole, are simple.  They look good enough that they'll get the job done but they won't be winning any awards.  The game allows you to import models and textures, so your mileage may vary, as well.  The backdrop for the "rooms" use a 4800x2400 HDRI Panorama shot, which means seams won't be an issue.  Overall, passable for what needs to be done.Gameplay:Tabletop Simulator is, as the name says, a game used to simulate various tabletops.  You start off with a decent number of standard board and card games, most pretty typical for what you'd see.  They're nice, but not exactly something I'd pay 20$ for flat out(But I'm a bit stingy), although the ability to play in a system that's not automated is nice.That leads into my next point:  The game isn't automated for the most part.  Everything is pretty customizable, and you can do various things, such as set hidden zones, flick items around, throw them around, flip tables, etc etc, with almost, if not all of it being able to be changed for your benefit(Of particular note is that you can disable the Table Flip option, thank god).  Leading to a pretty fun experience of just sitting around a table and BS'ing with friends.My one MAJOR issue with the gameplay is that you cannot peek at a card while it is face down outside of moving it into a hidden zone(Which is a bit cumbersome) or returning it to your hand(Which has its own fair share of complications)Workshop Support:This game allows you to create objects, texture them, and use them to make your own various games.  The system of doing so is relatively simple, as long as you know your way around models and textures, and it's pretty open, allowing you to import your own models into the game as well.  This is where the game shines, as almost any card or board game is possible with what is given to you.  The little figure can even be given animations for attacking and the like, to simulate an RPG.Along with that, there are various tools inserted in the game to help you accomplish this.  From counters, to tablets, to MP3 players, to calculators, and more.  And ALL of this can be uploaded and downloaded from the Steam Workshop, with download times being reduced due to the ability of Tabletop Simulator streaming image content from a hosted site(Which is both a blessing and a curse, to be honest).Honestly, all of it is really nice, my only problem with the modular ability of this game is that it seems like you can't plug your own MP3s into the MP3 player and you can't import custom tables, which is a shame, as that would have made RPGs truly perfect for this system.  Both of these can be worked around but it leads to an experience that is less than perfect.Overall:At the end of the day, Tabletop Simulator is a great game that allows people to just instantly pick up a deck or a pair of dice and play their favorite games.  It isn't perfect, and it won't ever be a true replacement for sitting around a table with your friends, but for those who are separated by long distances, this is a great alternative that will be sure to keep everyone happy.  It has a few issues but it's constantly being updated and I hope these will be sorted out in time.  Something else I want to note is that, while the DLC is a bit heavily priced, only one person needs to own it, which is..pretty much how it goes in real life, so I really appreciate and respect that.Overall, I'd give this game a 9/10, and I'd definitely recommend it to anyone.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2016
												A tabletop physics engine allowing more control for an organized social event than tools for griefers; anyone joining a game can slap the cards out of your hand, but the host can almost instantly ban, and reverse the damage done by rewinding time. Everything works really intuitively, objects snap and cascade by physically stacking, like chips and cards. Dice rolls with satisfying thuds like 45 grams of the finest plastic four sided cube on 19th century rosewood table. And if you highlight multiple dice, it tallies the total for you.All game states can be saved and loaded, by any of the 8 players joined, with permissions allowed by the host ofcourse. With integrated voice chat, turn indicators, handzones and private zones for hiding your hand/dice, it brings a lot of games to the table. Also, all types of objects can be customized with its own models, physics, and textures.The game grants you objects like cards, poker chips, coins, dice (d3, d4, d6, d20, etc.,) and figurines (chess/d&d). Objects snap and cascade by physically stacking, like chips and cards. You can shuffle cards by just pressing R, animation takes less than a second and is heard by all players. Then you can deal to everyone's hand just by clicking a button. Where the host controls the permissions of how every player interacts with the environment with a dropdown checklist. With a maximum of 8 players, it is really multiplayer tabletop games.Also, there’s a tablet simulator that links to google and youtube, that can be seen by every player on the table. Movie/music night?The advance features, like tape measurements, allows accuracy POV/LOS action figure games, like Warhammer 40k to be simulated perfectly. All you need is a brain for storing the codex rules, and the figurines available on the mod page. You measure 6” for walking infantry, toss a grenade and borrow the 3” blast marker available on the workshop page. When you shoot, you just lower your camera onto the table, and get an accurate Line of Sight from the space marine’s point of view.Game's good.

Orbiting a chess nerd flipping a table after a check-mate... yes.So much more, just get this. It's early access with all of this? Oh my, I am exited. Please, support these guys.Just my 2 cents. -Pj

As an only child growing up with a single parent, there was never really anyone to play board games with. Even now, I don't have a lot of local friends outside of my husband who are down to set up a game of DnD or Monopoly and play into the wee hours of the night. content:
Posted: March 18, 2016
												Great Simulator! Missing some sort of paper tracking mod or feature for character sheets. You have an index card...but not enough space to keep any additional info. I give it 3.5 stars in its current state for rpgs..but would happily give it 5 if they would add virtual paper.Update: 3/20/16 - I wanted to also mention as of right now no PDF support (it did at one time). You have to save a pic of a character sheet upload it to imgur. Get the link to the pic. Bring in an additioanl table in game. Paste the image link to the table. This is the only proper way to see a character sheet. The character sheet can not be edited or modified. You will have to bring in a new sheet using a new image with all the above steps.Update: 3/24/16 As of this date I was able to use PDF's on a tablet. We are moving in the right direction. Now all we need is a sheet of paper (e.g character sheet) for tracking purposes. 4 Stars at the time of this review....Come on 5 stars!

content:
Posted: April 10
												You don't need a long drawn out review to be convinced about this. If you like board games of any kind, and can put up with a small learning curve for clunky mouse controls, this game opens up an entirely new virtual board game experience for an incredible value/$. TL;DR, I bought a copy, then bought 4 more for friends.I watched the video for the game through my queue, I wasn't impressed. I assumed it was chess, checkers, some weird figurines, etc. Then I realized that it is really a gateway, or a games platform of it's own. When you get Tabletop Simulator, you are essentially buying access to every board game ever made, through the workshop, posted by other people who have a passion for those games. This includes games you've probably never heard of; Star Realms, Monopoly, Risk, Pandemic, 7 Wonders, Dominions, Citadels, Scythe, Carcassone, Life, and hundreds more.When I started getting into the new generation of board games with my friends, I picked up Tabletop Simulator on a recommendation. My mind was blown.The extra tools make playing better, click a button to shufle a deck, deal cards, roll dice dispense money and more. There are virtual tablets to google rules for games without leaving tabletop simulator, equal parts novel and suprisingly useful.

content:
Posted: April 18, 2014
Early Access Review
								The Good:  I've only mucked about on this for about 10 minutes so far, and yes, this IS an Early Access game, but so far, I see this as a WONDERFUL tool for table top gamers (board games, RPG's, miniatures, etc).  From what I've seen on the Forums, the Devs are going to update content (a tape measure is one of the ones they've talked about...for miniature gaming), so this is going to add even more variation to the creation and game play.  I love the physics involved in the game, things like picking up and moving the pieces, shuffling cards, rolling dice, and even flipping the table (yes...that flipping the table).The Bad:  It's Early Access...it's effectively a beta...so right now, you pretty much have the basic stuff in the game.  There is a thread on the Forums regarding the use of copyrighted material...this can hamper some of the more popular "games" being reproduced.The Ugly:  The "game room" is...well...empty...there's the table...but no walls, no floor...just the table (this is something that is added later).That's really it...I enjoy the games so far, I hope that more is added in and that copyright holders allow for their products to be added to the Steam Workshop (when that's added).

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 19, 2014
Early Access Review
								After trying out a bit of the game I must say this is a really awesome "simulator". The lawlessness of it really makes it feel like you're playing a game with your friends, and really the entire playthrough of each game is entirely dependant on the integrity and self control of the party members. I don't really have too many complaints so far, and I also know this is still in beta however... I feel that this game needs a system that allows for more orginized play throughs. The only other things that I'd like to be changed/added would be the following.       This game really shouldn't market itself as a lawless game where you can just rage whenever, that's just the nonsense-type "fun" that is very temporary and well... it makes games boring quickly. (Especially in this "simulator" genre). In terms of the game and what it should provide, I do not know the intentions of the developers but these games are the real basic classics, they're very simple games and as much as I love them, i'd like to see some more elaborate-modern type games, heck even monoploy would be nice to see. I don't care if it's made up or based on another board game, I just want more of a variety with much more replayability then these classics. That's really what I feel this game needs. Lastly the game should have a GUI system, one to enhance the playability of game modes, be it one that issues money to players to add gambling, or something that could allow for further development of the games. That'd be great. Overall what I enjoy the most within this game is it's freedom, it allows for an intimacy and looseness that simulates real life board games with family and friends. It's physics are great. (I would only fix the perspective of the table to it's background (Which isn't really a big deal and has little to do with the physics). I just see that this game really has a lots of amazing potential. I know that this game is still in early access but i'd like for the developers to strongly consider at least some of these things. Thanks for reading through my "review" or rather rambling thoughts, I hope some of these suggestions come to the attention of the developers.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 1, 2016
												I think I really underestimated how good this game could be before I bought it. I honestly thought it was just some kind of joke after seeing all the table flipping videos and thought it would just be a physics simulator. The possibilites in this game are quite literally endless. I\'ve already played Tokaido, Chinese Checkers, Blackjack and Snakes and Ladders. This is a really good simulator because it\'s actually so much like real life and you don\'t have to spend loads of money on the real thing. Even the drawing mechanics make this enjoyable alone. You can play pen & paper games like Tic Tac Toe, Hangman or Dots and Boxes.I thought I might not have enjoyed this game prior to buying it because a lot of videos suggested that you need friends for it to work but playing on random servers worked the best for me as this game has one of the best communities I\'ve ever seen.9.5/10

Early Access Review
								This is as close as you get to playing board games with others irl. The current custom game modes are automatically shown to anyone who joins the server so you don't even need to download any mods to play online (unless you want to host a certain game mode not in game already).The future holds custom 3d model support (for game pieces and the like,) more tabletop rpg support, and more game modes. But, seriously, tablets.

												Amazing game that is well worth the money! Playing board games on Tabletop Simulator doesn't feel as shallow as it would when you play other online board games. I like that you have to move and keep track of everything yourself. This is a blast to play with a group of people! With tons of content available in the workshop, I can see myself playing this for a very long time. It is even easy to recreate games of your choosing since the included deck editor basically does the work for you. Posted: June 14, 2015
												It's a card game or what we think it is. It's more of a physics sandbox game where you can spawn regular cards or board games and equipment or you can just play by the rules before someone can flip the table out of rage! Including Steam workshop for additional games and fun content to spawn and play.So basicly, my first time playing this game was with a friend of mine to show me the ropes and random workshop items. Next time I launch the game, I was looking for a Cards Against Humanity server, and I did. Played a couple of rounds and swap games as a group. Next thing you know, tablets and porn. I came back to the server and 2 of my new friends were spawning in tablets and started to looking up porn. How am I suppose to explain that? "I'm masterbating with my friends?"But great game, I highly recommend it. Vote 10/10 for Jackie Chan fighting ninjas while handling a homemade come stained Star Trek uniform (CAH).

content:
Posted: November 16, 2016
I nominate this game for the "Game Within A Game" award Great dedicated devs and an AMAZING modding community make Tabletop Simulator a must have for pretty much anyone slightly interested in board games, cards games and so on.With more than 15.000 mods, TTS it's the perfect way to try a board game before buying it, to teach other people or to discover - and learn - new incredible games. The variety of the mods cover pretty much every category, from Classics like Go, Mastermind or Ticket to Ride to hidden gems, from Warhammer Fantasy/40.000 or Kings of War to Flames of War and Heroscape, from Betrayal at the house to Dead of Winter, from very complex wargames (GMT and Coin series) to X-Wing and so on. You can even play Magic The Gathering or D&D. Both local or online. There is really no limits to what you can play on TTS. Get it.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												Tabletop Simulator is not a game.  Tabletop Simulator is a system for playing board and card games.  It does this fairly well, and if you have a group of nerdy friends that are all willing to learn to use an initially awkward interface you can have fun with it.  If you don't, there are public rooms available for games.    This game is quite useful if you design your own board games and are looking for a way to test your prototypes with people online.  There are a few communities of people that trade playtesting on this service.

content:
Posted: March 3
												You'll primarily want to be playing things that have at most one or two simple tasks for a player to accomplish at a time. It can get finicky with too many pieces or decks to place things on. Make sure to have a decent mic, it makes a huge load of a difference in ease of play. Overall, if you're careful with game selection, you can hammer out most titles in perhaps 125% of the time they take in real life, which isn't too shabby. It handles Cosmic Encounter, the greatest game, admirably - which alone is enough to give it the thumbs up.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 27
												First and foremost this is a simulator of a table top, there is no AI, can you play solo yes and many of the board games allow for solo play especially co-op games.  In most cases you need to know the rules, the games often don't have rules with them. Most cases just go download a PDF of the rules, they are out there  on the internet somewhere, and in some cases the mod developers will put the link in the game.  If you are expecting the game to do the work for you, not going to happen, you are in control, if you are lucky someone has scripted a few things but for the most part it is like walking up to the table, setting up the game to some degree and playing.  I love the coop games, and have played a couple that I own using this simulator and I am quite pleased with the way it works.  They are great for practice runs of games as you try to learn the rules.  So far I have tried Pandemic: Cthulhu version, Arkahm Horror the Card Game, One Deck Dungeon, and just set up Arkham Horror the Core game.  IF you like the games, then you are encourage to go out and buy a physical copy of the game, in some cases not as easy as it sounds.  Final Fantasy, has a lot of games that are waiting to be shipped, reprinted and sadly in some cases are no longer in print.  But Board Game Geek market can be your friend.  I do admit that I find the interface clunky at times, as you have to often bring up cards to see them (Easy using Alt).  But heck with my eye sight I have to bring cards up to read them anyway, so as stated you get a table top feel for the games.  Like in real life, things fall over,  you can even flip the who board if you want.  Thankfully it has a recall last using a back arrow, then it just sets up from the last position of the game.9/10 I think on this one.  Play Games here, buy games and support your local game store.  The interface also has built in hosting and I believe chat too.  So you can host a game with your friends.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												Basically you get what's in the title. You can have a table online with other people, and play games together.  Pretty straightfoward, and well-implemented it seems.Of course the main focus of this is gaming.  It comes with several traditional games (chess, poker, so on...and to my delight, Go), and there are optional DLC games, that honestly did not interest me one bit.  But there is Steam Workshop and mod sites which let you play actual games, and more.  Since I have had this, I've gotten to play some new games I've never played before, and I discovered some old favorites on the workshop.  For something like D&D, though, it can take some work.  I haven't tried to run or join a game with it, but I think it would not be too much trouble to import maps.  It can also do not-so-game stuff, if you can find the tools (or figure out how to make your own).  Anything you could do around a table, more or less.  I set it up to do tarot readings, and that seems to work nicely.  The biggest complaint I hear is that it's expensive.  That's really up to the buyer, and what you expect to get out of it.  I would think it's worth it, but for RPGs there are other alternatives that don't cost $20.

content:
Posted: June 9, 2016
												I was extremely skeptical when I saw this game. It looked clunky and weird and it was hard to visualize actually utilizing it for anything. Now that I have given it a go, I am nothing but impressed with this. TTS allows avid board game players to play in a REALLY convenient way. You just load up whatever board game you want to play (and there are TONS of mods for pretty much any board game, like how can this even be legal?!), invite your friends to the game, and go. You can even save games and come back to them later, which is super useful for extremely long and involved games. If you are into board games, I can't recommend this game enough.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 12, 2016
												Cool application, more of a tool than a game, to simulate playing tabletop games with friends.You can tell that it started as a non-serious attempt of a game (just simulate playing chess and checkers on a virtual table with gravity and physics and be able to flip the table, ha-ha), but as it became more and more popular, the developers started shaping it up into a really feature-complete program.Now the game includes almost everything you need (besides friends) to enjoy boardgames, role-playing, or just simulate sitting on a table with another person watching youtube videos and hanging around.I recommend it because it is the best at what it does, and fills a niche that was vacant for a long time. The developers are also very active and keep on adding features and fixing bugs. However I would point out some negatives:-The game has a form of DRM, even though the kickstarter campaign promised it to be DRM-free. Personally I would like to have a tool like this available forever to play with my friends, instead of depending on developer-run servers.-Since it is in constant evolution, updates to the game sometimes break or remove previous features that worked OK. The developers have stated that they do not plan to support older versions, and in fact do not offer them for download.-The game is advertised as cross-platform, but mac and linux versions have lower priority for bug fixing, from what I've seen.Even with these negatives, there are no alternatives to this game with the same functionality, so get it if you need it.I didn't mention VR because I don't own the hardware, but that is another point in favor of this game for some of you.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												Time for a bunch of rambling thoughts in no particular order:As a friend of mine described it, this is "gMod but for board games". The Lua update has only made this even more apt. If there's a game you've ever played (or wanted to play), it's in here. The #1 board game product for people with a severe lack of IRL friends, or non-standard work schedules. The board game world is so much larger than Monopoly and Risk, and that's not even mentioning the rabbit hole that is Tabletop RPG's. A great way to make (and occasionally break) friendships. All the fun of table flipping with none of the mess. Digital setup and aids for games that are normally clunky irl and easy saves/loading for games you'd normally devote an entire day to, but can now play in 2 hour slices. No cats jumping on the table. Realistic dice that are fun to roll. Rapid prototyping for any board game you might have in your head. Cheap and easily accessible digital versions of a variety of party games, both official versions and unofficial. Runs smoothly on a potato, but can take advantage of powerful systems too (did I mention VR?). Play games with irl mates that have moved away, no longer does physical separation mean board game night (or RPG night) is over. And more.Buy it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												A must-have for every board game enthusiast.You can play with friends that are far away - or join a completely random party game with some strangers (Secret Hitler is just great, look for servers!). You can learn rules for your new games in a single player mode before getting them on a table. You can try out something from your BoardGameGeek wishlist before buying it, there are tons of awesome games in the Workshop (Star Wars Series, Tragedy Looper, Betrayal at House on the Hill, Lewis & Clark, Android Netrunner - these are just some of my favorites). You can make your own epic DnD campaigns. You can flip the table in a fit of rage and watch millions of pieces falling into the abyss. The possibilities are infinite!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6, 2016
												100/10 IGNThe first thing I would like to say is that I have over one thousand hours on this game. Each, and every single hour was played. Not a single time did I start the game and just leave it on. That is a small way to sum up how much I truly adore this game. If you dislike tabletop games, then this is not for you. Do not buy this game just to flip tables or dismantle other people's games, because theres an easy banning system which can stop people within seconds. You're not even permenantly disrupting the game, because of the rewind feature. If you actually enjoy tabletop games, whether it's Cards Against Humanity, RPG's, or King of New York, then this is for you. It takes a bit to get used to all the controls, but after your first hour or so you'll have everything down if you went through the tutorial. This game is limitless in it's possabilities. I could litterally play almost any game, even if it's not actually a board game. Someone made a 100% Orange Juice replica in this, which is a great video game. The overall community is great, and eventually you will make friends from this game whether you like it or not. You'll come across people who enjoy the same games as you, and that's something I've yet to experience from any other game. Something that can sit me down and allow me to find someone with similar interests.

content:
Posted: August 5, 2016
												Tabletop Simulator (TTS) is exactly what it sounds like. It is a program that allows you to play pretty much any "analogue" game that you can think of, on the computer. While it will never replace the tactile feel that you get from holding actual game pieces or cards, nor the joy of sitting at a table with a bunch of other people who enjoy the game you are playing, it has so many benefits that any fan of any table top game needs to own this.First, you can theoretically play literally any tabletop game that exists in real life, on TTS. The mod community has shown a lot of hard work and creativity when it comes to available games on this. Aside from the standard games like Chess that already come with this game, you can play popular board games like the very popular, but much maligned Monopoly, to board game fan classic Battlestar Galactica. Even miniature games like Warhammer and Guild Ball are available to play. Want to play a LCG like Netrunner or Doomtown, but don’t want to shell out the hundreds of dollar’s worth of card expansions? It’s here too. If you have an idea for your own game, you can make it here too. The best part however, is it allows you to play these games at any time, even if your friends live far away, or if none of them are available. There is a community out there who wants to play these games. If you like table top games at all, and wish you could play them more often: get this game.9/10 “Excellent”

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												Basically you get what's in the title. You can have a table online with other people, and play games together.  Pretty straightfoward, and well-implemented it seems.Of course the main focus of this is gaming.  It comes with several traditional games (chess, poker, so on...and to my delight, Go), and there are optional DLC games, that honestly did not interest me one bit.  But there is Steam Workshop and mod sites which let you play actual games, and more.  Since I have had this, I've gotten to play some new games I've never played before, and I discovered some old favorites on the workshop.  For something like D&D, though, it can take some work.  I haven't tried to run or join a game with it, but I think it would not be too much trouble to import maps.  It can also do not-so-game stuff, if you can find the tools (or figure out how to make your own).  Anything you could do around a table, more or less.  I set it up to do tarot readings, and that seems to work nicely.  The biggest complaint I hear is that it's expensive.  That's really up to the buyer, and what you expect to get out of it.  I would think it's worth it, but for RPGs there are other alternatives that don't cost $20.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
												Writing a review for this is basically writing a review for every tabletop game ever made. So I am gonna ask you this instead:Do you like tabletop games?Do you want to play them online?Do you want to play them with real physics and (theoretically) no restricting rules? 												In all honesty I'm just writing this review to earn badges, but while I'm at it I might as well write a little something about TTS, no?If you're unsure whether or not you should buy this I can tell you a few reasons you'd want to check to make sure it's worth it for you.1. Do your friends own it and you enjoy playing tabletop games?2. Do you enjoy playing around with physics?3. Do you want/need some sort of software to try out a game before you buy it in real life? (Yeah yeah, not all games exist for this yet, but there's a lot of them and more are constantly added.)4. Want the satisfaction of flipping the table after you lose? (Granted, you're going to need the host's permission to do this, but you know.)If at least 2 of those get checked by you, I say buy it. It's not the best way to play tabletop games, but it is a really good substitute, even more so if the people you want to play with are in other countries. Like any software/game you'll find yourself annoyed at certain things, but in my experience with TTS, these things are so minor that you'll overlook them immediately.A few things that I've found myself getting a little annoyed over include physics not always working as they should because of a workshop item not being completely refined and certain scanned items not being readable.All annoyances are either small enough to just ignore or easily worked around.It's easy to recommend this to anyone who's looking to play some tabletop games with friends in other countries or just wants to try out a few games before going to pick them up in real life.

content:
Posted: May 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								In order to understand this game, You have to be a gamer. And not the normal gamer of today, one whose in a college frat playing cod, or a 10 year old who screamed his head off until his parents got him that M rated game... This is a game about imagination, Simplicity, Friendship, and most importantly... Strategy. This simulator allows you to run servers that can play board games. Games like Monopoly, Risk, Life, Ticket to Ride, Carcassone, and many many others. But it also allows you to run card games like Cards against Humanity, or Apples to Apples, or Uno, and again, many many others. And of course this game allows you to play any RPG dungeoun crawler/adeventure/Story-driven game your little heart can imagine. In my years of gaming, This is the most complete version of the physical, becoming the Digital. And i adore it.If you like playing board games, RPGs, or card games AT ALL, play this game. Any gamer should play this game. Its the greatest thing gamers could ask for.Also the graphics are really good...10/10 take all the tens!!!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								A game where what you do can do things as though you and your friends were at an actual table playing whatever comes to mind, ranging from board games (such as Chess, Go, and Reversi), card games, to rpg role playing. All without the mess and streamlined actions for dealing and cleaning up cards. It even has gravity settings and blocks to play with.Further possibilities are added when you throw in board and deck importing into the mix. You're basically capable of playing any board game that exists as long as you or someone else knows how to make it. The possibilities are almost limitless, and this may even allow for new tabletop games to come to life, allowing for a potential whole new wave of board games.It can be a brilliant game for classic tabletop fun or for complete hilarity, allowing you to do things you wouldn't normally be able to do in your house, and even allowing you to do table flips. It's your choice.Probably one of the most simplistically innovative ideas for a game out there. I recommend it to the highest degree.Oh I almost forgot, make sure you have friends to play this with- you could always play online, but it's nothing like having you and a bunch of your friends at the same table messing around.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 25, 2015
												A physics sandbox simulating a table for the purpose of all manner of tabletop games - Board Games, Card Games, Pen-and-Paper RPGs, Jigsaw Puzzles, etc.  With an extensive Workshop selection of user-made content many popular childhood games can be found.I've used it to host table-top RPGs and card games and even just sitting around BSing with friends is enjoyable.  With some playful props thrown in and everyone chatting, It definately feels as close to sitting around a table as it can get without engaging webcams.  There'sd no AI so rules are not artifically enforced, if a player wants to cheat by moving out of turn or swapping the places of a Knight and a Rook - just like in real life - there's nothing stopping them but honest.  However, there are physics mechanics in play to keep objects from slopping around the board.  Pieces can be hard- and soft-locked in place so accidental nudging doesn't ruin a carefully laid board and pieces can optionally snap to a grid.  -  Just enough framework to allow things to work well and avoid chaos without being restrictive and 'too much like a videogame'.I highly recommend TTS to anyone who enjoys any manner of tabletop games.  I was skeptical but saw that the game had potential and am very pleased to say that it's lived up to my expectations and surpassed them.

Early Access Review
								This game provided a fun alternative to going to a tabletop game store and spending 40 bucks on a board game that will only get use once or twice a month for a few months.The game is easy to mod and so long as you know what you're doing, you can create your own decks of cards with ease and editing the model logic is simple with some rendering software or experience doing so.My only gripe is that you cannot publish privately to Steam right now. I have a custom game that I made that I want to release to my friends but don't want to be posted publically at this point... it would be nice to be able to use steam's workshop for the release instead of having to manually update their files.Overall though, once you get the controls down, this is a good option for trying out new desktop games before you buy them or if you are trying to juggle busy schedules.

								Tabletop Sim is a fantastic addition to the simulator genre. I wouldn't really class it as a simulator though. It's better than that- much more, I can play almost any card and board game(and tons which don't even exist... yet thanks to the creative tools within) digitally with my friends and family anywhere in the world. I move a lot, so having this ability is extremely important and is why Tabletop Simulator gets a strong recommendation from me.+ Creativity (Make almost any game that you would play on a tabletop, and even invent your own).+ Replayability (With the large variety of games and mods available you will find it hard to run out of things to do.+ Utility (Play with anyone and just about anywhere- that an internet connection is available)- Not free (Well worth the asking price though!)

content:
Posted: December 5, 2014
Early Access Review
								Picked this up randomly, had been following it for a while.  Upon loading the game after picking a few workshop items I was blown away!  The peices move and animate, the simulation of a table top and all the glory and possible peril of organizing peices combine with the purely endless possibilities.  Just paging through the workshop and loading up tables and messing with it gave me that feeling I used to get when arriving to a friends house in middle school and getting out my character sheet and my tube of dice (which usually lacked a d20 because everyone stole everyones dice).  Its a great idea, implimented incredibly well with room to improve and some pretty impressive features.  So glad this has been made.  Now to get back in touch with my old D&D cohorts and M:TG friends and start a whole new Golden age of tabletop gaming.

												    One of the favourite games in my library. It is very easy to learn the controls and jump into an open lobby, but unfortunately there is basically no variety in public games. After about 2 months you will either have to play the same games you've played multiple times before, or host your own game (but be prepared to teach the newcomers). If you can convince your friends to get the game as well, you will have much more fun playing with them instead of strangers. Private matches > Public matches.

content:
Posted: January 7
												Tabletop piracy made even more convinent.  10/10 love not paying for things.I usually dont make joke reviews like this, but there is seriously nothing else I want to say about this game.  The controls work, the community can be a bit toxic at times but is overall pretty fun to play in public lobbies or friends alike.  The only reason this game is in my personal favorites is because it allows me to test out real life tabletop games without having to spend money on them right away.  I ended up finding one of my favorite, casual strategy/chess variant games(Input) through the workshop.  But yeah, the workshop contains about 95% total disregard for product copyright.  You play this to pirate stuff, not to prototype new games like the developers shamelessly advertised it as early on.  Please, if you play this game, and you have real life friends to invite over for a night of tabletop games, respect the people who gave you these concepts.  Buy the physical games.  Or at least buy the DLC and not the ghetto workshop versions of said DLC...

								This is probably the most interesting use of a physics engine that I've seen so far. Rather than limit you to a series of 'planned' interactions with the 'game' the engine merely responds to how you move the pieces. So this is basically a true 'sandbox' in the sense that you can do whatever you want and the engine doesn't get in the way if possible. It might be a little frustrating for people who are looking for a dedicated poker game, or a dedicated chess game, etc etc, but for tabletop gamers....There's an RPG set that looks like it can be used for D&D, GURPS, etc with an in-the-works 'character sheet;' could this seriously mean that D&D could move to virtual pen and paper?

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								Imagine this, you're on Skype with your buddies, when you start saying something like "I wish we could play board games together". Yeah, there are sites online with that kind of stuff, but they're kinda lifeless.Yeah, you can buy "Monopony" or whatever on Steam, but there's no online multiplayer.With this Early Access simulator game, you can do whatever the hell you feel like, and you just pay once. Plus, if you're looking at this, chances are, you have a Steam account, as well as Steam friends.Just take a quick look at the workshop at the games people put. Monopoly, Cards Against Humanity, Risk, UNO, Scrabble, Candy Land, Sorry!, the list goes on.There are even different themes for games. Nintendo Monopoly, Sonic Monopoly, Mass Effect Go Fish (I'm serious).Being an Early Access game, things are being changed all the time and there's bound to be issues, but even in its current state, it's certainly worth a buy.Is there anything I wish could be changed? Well, yeah, a couple.1. Custom model imports for game pieces.Earlier I mentioned Monopoly. Well, there's no house models, so you have to do like Chess pieces or something in their place. There's also no cats, shoes, cars, or anything. Just standard game pieces. I think adding custom models would make things very neat.2. Adjust the gravity a little for certain objects.I notice when I turn the gravity up, the game pieces move like I want, but then the dice is a little heavy. Maybe there can be sliders for dice, coins, game pieces, and whatever else.3. Tags or Descriptions for game rooms.Yeah, there's the name section, but people put their username or something silly there. Nobody puts what game it is. How about an extra section that lists the game from Workshop currently in use.Like: (Room name) (Host name) (Workshop item name)And if they're using a custom game, just let the user type in the game and that'll show.But even without these, this is simply pure raw fun. Sure, the players have to enforce the rules, but that goes for real board games as well.Recommended for those who have online friends who you really want to play board games with. For 15 bucks, it's worth it.

content:

Early Access Review
								Quite a nice little game. Basically a board game simulator with the added fun of physics to create a more Sandbox like feel to the game.Out of the box, the game comes with a couple of popular board games to get you started: Backgammon, Cards (Limitless amount of games here, although the game does come with Poker chips should we want to partake any money centred card games), chess, checkers and even an RPG dungeons and dragons style kit so you can create dungeon advantures.Where the game really excels at is the community behind the game as well, a large array of additional games can be downloaded for free from the Steam Workshop with cards and custom model support you can play a number of games.The game also comes with internet multiplayer support can you can mess about with your friends over a virtual table top.Oh and yes, you can flip tables. :)Nifty game, would reccomend purchasing if it goes on sale.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												Very, very great and rather fun game. There's an extremely large variety of games/board games to play from the steam workshop, the global chat is usually pretty friendly and there's usually people asking if others want to play a game. As well, if you don't have anyone to play with, finding a game to join by talking to people in the global chat or joining an outside community (like The Red Dice) is pretty easy.Definitely worth getting. The only small bit of frustrating or baffling thing could be learning how to actually play some games because if you're just reading the manual or rules by yourself, it can be a bit confusing how the game works. Nonetheless, that's how it is with real new board games, so that's not a valid complaint. And anyways, it's very simple to either watch videos of people playing the game on Youtube or so, or even just joining a lobby and telling them you've never played before. People are usually pretty good about explaining how to play, and when you do this, you at least know that you're definitely playing the game right.Again, would totally, totally recommend. So fun and entertaining.

content:
Posted: April 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								A very fun Simulator with great multiplayer. The game is a simple concept, but the details add immensely to the fun and value during multiplayer. Host a server easily or join one. Quickly choose between lots of common games (Chess, Checkers etc.). I play cards a lot- the host can quickly deal cards to everyone and shuffle simply by clicking. You can see where each player's cursor is, and you can drag and drop betting chips. You can chat easily during the game through voice or chat. Little noises liek chips clicking and cards shuffling add to the game. You can manipulate the game chips which adds to the "physicality" of the player-game interaction.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
												Unlimited possibilities, and it ain't lying.  The only limit is your imagination.There is an absolute minimum amount of hand holding.  If you play Battleship, you will have to vocally call out the attack, and respond with hit or miss.  You have to drag the little piece to the board to fill out the grid yourself.  If you play poker, you actually have to deal the cards and count the chips.  In Jumanji, you're responsible for releasing your own wild animals (0/10).  That's really my only gripe, some workshop maps offer some scripting, but I'd like to see a bit more hand holding (like an auto dealer for hold'em, a chip counter for gambling, persistent servers, some self moving pieces).  You can cheat, you can flip the table, you can rage flick your buddies piece, and you can even play board games.  Highly recommended.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												The wonderful thing about Tabletop Simulator isn't it's depth or it's innovation, but it's ability to take a classically local scenario and expand it on a global scale. I love board games, but I often find them painstakingly long to set up and even harder to find people to play with sometimes. But with TTS, I can message my friends and within minutes have a game set up and running. The connection has always been terrific, the base content is solid, and the seamless ability to bring in new content through the Steam Workshop ensures that TTS will have a place in my library for a long, long time. TTS is one of the best social interactions I've had on Steam in a long while, and as more and more people add it to their collections, I can only imagine that will continue to improve.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
												With a wide variety of board games brought to you by the game's harmonious relationship between an outstanding community and developers that actually listen, Tabletop Sim is easily one of the hidden gems of Steam's 2016 summer sale.Aside from just the classics the devs have listed, buying this game has officially given you a swiss army knife that has almost any well-known game you've played on a table with your friends. For those that hate the idea of getting your friends together in person (or just hate people in general), the company this game keeps is relatively small but kind. Occasionally you'll get the tard who excessively flips tables or moves♥♥♥♥♥♥around, but there are mods in place that frequently saves progress and kick features. There's even a main chat at the starting screen to encourage people to play together. In my first 90 minutes of gameplay, I think it's safe to say that I prefer the company of these strangers. The tablet and mp3 functions also allow for you to listen to stock music that you've heard a million times on top of full google access to a small screen that everyone sees in game. Tie that to the games soothing backgrounds, and you've got one of the most relaxing environments to simulate boardgames in. There's nothing like it. In short, the game's got two things going for it - a tremendous community of nice people and limitless game diversity. While you don't need it, you should get the DLCs that appeal to you only to show appreciation for the devs. I'd consider this a must-buy.

content:
Posted: July 21, 2016
												Wanted to play some tabletop games with friends, was on sale, didn't know if that was going to happen and thought lets do a jiggsaw puzzle for an hour and refund it if necessary... spent 10 hours obsessed with jiggsaw puzzles. Friend gets the game, let's play card games with him for hours, flip some tables, do more jiggsaws, flip more tables, browse the workshop, table flipping and jiggsawing.some bulletpoints- Best sandbox boardgame sim available so far- Jiggsaws- Needs more resolutions for custom jiggsaw pictures and needs a higher piece count- great for card games and tcgs, has a intuitive peek function that tells you who peeks at what card.- Official DLC for games with their own backgrounds and more (only host needs to own the game)- great selection of workshop mods to choose fromCan recommend even at full price!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								A game where what you do can do things as though you and your friends were at an actual table playing whatever comes to mind, ranging from board games (such as Chess, Go, and Reversi), card games, to rpg role playing. All without the mess and streamlined actions for dealing and cleaning up cards. It even has gravity settings and blocks to play with.Further possibilities are added when you throw in board and deck importing into the mix. You're basically capable of playing any board game that exists as long as you or someone else knows how to make it. The possibilities are almost limitless, and this may even allow for new tabletop games to come to life, allowing for a potential whole new wave of board games.It can be a brilliant game for classic tabletop fun or for complete hilarity, allowing you to do things you wouldn't normally be able to do in your house, and even allowing you to do table flips. It's your choice.Probably one of the most simplistically innovative ideas for a game out there. I recommend it to the highest degree.Oh I almost forgot, make sure you have friends to play this with- you could always play online, but it's nothing like having you and a bunch of your friends at the same table messing around.

content:
Posted: September 25, 2015
												A physics sandbox simulating a table for the purpose of all manner of tabletop games - Board Games, Card Games, Pen-and-Paper RPGs, Jigsaw Puzzles, etc.  With an extensive Workshop selection of user-made content many popular childhood games can be found.I've used it to host table-top RPGs and card games and even just sitting around BSing with friends is enjoyable.  With some playful props thrown in and everyone chatting, It definately feels as close to sitting around a table as it can get without engaging webcams.  There'sd no AI so rules are not artifically enforced, if a player wants to cheat by moving out of turn or swapping the places of a Knight and a Rook - just like in real life - there's nothing stopping them but honest.  However, there are physics mechanics in play to keep objects from slopping around the board.  Pieces can be hard- and soft-locked in place so accidental nudging doesn't ruin a carefully laid board and pieces can optionally snap to a grid.  -  Just enough framework to allow things to work well and avoid chaos without being restrictive and 'too much like a videogame'.I highly recommend TTS to anyone who enjoys any manner of tabletop games.  I was skeptical but saw that the game had potential and am very pleased to say that it's lived up to my expectations and surpassed them.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
												Unlimited possibilities, and it ain't lying.  The only limit is your imagination.There is an absolute minimum amount of hand holding.  If you play Battleship, you will have to vocally call out the attack, and respond with hit or miss.  You have to drag the little piece to the board to fill out the grid yourself.  If you play poker, you actually have to deal the cards and count the chips.  In Jumanji, you're responsible for releasing your own wild animals (0/10).  That's really my only gripe, some workshop maps offer some scripting, but I'd like to see a bit more hand holding (like an auto dealer for hold'em, a chip counter for gambling, persistent servers, some self moving pieces).  You can cheat, you can flip the table, you can rage flick your buddies piece, and you can even play board games.  Highly recommended.

Early Access Review
								My lands... This game. This game is the game I've been waiting for, forever. I am such a huge fan of board games. My closet is fillled with them! And this game captures the feel almost perfectly. If you have a friend to play with then you have even greater of a reason to play this game! Man even I'll play this game with you if I'm not bust. Only thing that could make this game better is if they could get Fantasy Flight Games to sign an agreement to make expansion packs with their games. I heard they're working on Hasbro right now though. So one company at a time, eh? But back to this review. While I could ramble on forever, I'll try to close this up soon. So, yes get this game if you like board games at all because it captures the feeling. And if you're crafty enough you could play DnD in it now. It comes with some super detailed animated figures for RPG games! So if you and your friends bring thei rown character sheets and dungeon guide, I'm sure you could find a way to make it work! Get mad at it? it even lets you flip the table. So go on and help grow this game! Make it great and let Fantasy Flight see a reason to put their games in it!

Early Access Review
								Tabletop simulator is one of the most fun games to ever be put on steam,  The possibilities for this are endless.You can play ANY tabletop game you wish,  And if it does not exist in the workshop you can simply create it yourself with the in game editor which is very simple to use.Being yet another early access game I was a little reluctant to play it,  As I have had a few mixed feelings about other early access games. I am sure you will after playing this.I will confidently give this game a solid 10/10.

content:
Posted: September 5, 2014
Early Access Review
								If you have any love for card games, board games, or even pen-and-paper RPGs, this is as close as it gets to the real thing.Everything is affected by solid and reliable physics, and there's very little restriction to how you interact with the game pieces. You're open to just not playing the game at all and just screwing around with the pieces. Stage a soap opera with chess pieces, who cares.It's wide-open to custom content. You can make custom card decks with just image files, you can import models for custom figurines and game pieces, make your own custom boards, and it can all be uploaded to the Steam Workshop. Try to count how many variations of Monopoly you see.The online play is simple, stable, smooth, and the most well-synced of any physics-centric game I've played.With all that together, you can play basically any game that can be played on a table. 'Cept for games with moving parts. Like Mouse Trap or something.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 16, 2014
Early Access Review
								Tableflip Simulator.But in all seriousness, this is amazing. True dedication and work has been put into this, and it truly does what it aims to do, and it continues to do it better. PROS:Play with your friends.Play the games you love (Monopoly, Munchkin, etc. Find them on the workshop)Great piece control and systemCONS:Worried about copyright issues as far as games being put up by users on the workshop.Trying to do multiple things at once(I.E. zooming in on a piece you are holding) tends to be buggy for now. Not a true issue though.Initial load into a room is slow even on a high end computer due to intensive memory load and image processing. After this there are no real problems.EDIT: The recent update (v2.7 on 9/19/2014) fixes many of the memory issues, so if this was holding you back from buying this, DON'T LET IT :DWhat I would like to see:Character sheet supportPiece interaction support and health bars/stats applied to pieces. (I.E. Elf Attack-> Orc for 12 damage. -12 image over Orc, health bar, if known/visible, drains an appropriate amount.)EFFECTS! ALL THE EFFECTS! EXPLOSIONS! FOIL CARDS! CARDS THAT PROJECT 3D "HOLOGRAM" MODELS!Custom rooms, I wanna play in a nerd cave :PBeing able to lock pieces from specific players (I.E. John can pick this piece up, but Jenna cannot)This game is a Natural 20.Traditional score: 8.0/10.0Projected "on release" score: 9.5-10.0/10.0Buy it at $15? If your friends have it, or you have the money to spare, yes.Buy it on sale? I think this one answers itself.

												"I Thought This Game Was Cool Before It Won An Award"But besides that, I haven't come across any other software that mimics a 'virtual table' as good as this one has (especially with the [currently in development] VR support).* Simple to use* Easy to make custom content (at least, with some computer knowledge)* Built-in Online multiplayer* Vast array of existing games on the Workshop* Large friendly communityThis has become my software of choice when prototyping my own custom games with (I have spent many weekends making custom cards, boards, tiles, dice, etc for importing) and made it possible to easily play these games with friends and family from across the world.If you or your friends are into playing (or making!) board games (or similar), then I can't recommend this enough!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
												Tabletop Simulator aims to be the ideal platform to play games, traditionally limited to physical contact, anywhere in the world with anyone you want. This game has bridged long distance friendships and keeps board game night going no matter the distance. The game just gives you a sandbox to play in and doesn't force any tabletop game's rules on the players, this allows for any complexity of game to be played. All you need is to scan the board game's assets into the computer to play it digitally with friends. Have no idea how to do that? That's OK because one of this game's biggest strengths is it's mod support. Check out the Workshop and you will most likely find what you are looking for. I think this game should be a must have for anyone who enjoys traditional board, card and tabletop games.

content:

Early Access Review
								Tabletop simulator is an awesome platform for playing board- or cardgames with your friends. It's not for playing with random people online but rather for playing with friends or family. It's easy to use and with plenty of workshop content readily available, and if you are a little creative it is easy to create custom games or even invent your very own.The only thing that it needs is ingame customizable time keeping, like a one-click x-minute timer and I'd be able to create any game I want in it.Now if only you could buy a bundle when you already own the game, then I'd be buying the crap out of this game to gift to all my friends. Steam, PLEASE make this possible...

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								It's Gmod for board games!Graphics:The graphics aren't anything to shout about, but they are decent and nice to look at.Sound:Agains, nothing to shout about.  There's no music, so supply your own if need be.  The sounds that do come up are nice and sound like they should.Control:I use keyboard/mouse, but it seems it also supports controller.  You can move anythign and everything around and there are no issues that I found.Gameplay:This is where the game shines!  Not only are there several games already included, it supports Steam Workshop, which has LOTS of user created games as well as full recreations of established boardgames such adn Monopoly and Risk!  There are so many, I don't think you could get through them all, though there are a few user created ones that you might wanna pass up for various reasons.  But with up to player 8 online support and extensive Hosting tools, you and friends will have a HUGE blast with this game!  There is even support for Dungeons and Dragons miniatures, so you can host an online D&D session, which is great for those who want to roleplay, but don't live near people who do!I urge everyone to get this game!  This is the most awesome program for boardgame lovers!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								In order to understand this game, You have to be a gamer. And not the normal gamer of today, one whose in a college frat playing cod, or a 10 year old who screamed his head off until his parents got him that M rated game... This is a game about imagination, Simplicity, Friendship, and most importantly... Strategy. This simulator allows you to run servers that can play board games. Games like Monopoly, Risk, Life, Ticket to Ride, Carcassone, and many many others. But it also allows you to run card games like Cards against Humanity, or Apples to Apples, or Uno, and again, many many others. And of course this game allows you to play any RPG dungeoun crawler/adeventure/Story-driven game your little heart can imagine. In my years of gaming, This is the most complete version of the physical, becoming the Digital. And i adore it.If you like playing board games, RPGs, or card games AT ALL, play this game. Any gamer should play this game. Its the greatest thing gamers could ask for.Also the graphics are really good...10/10 take all the tens!!!

Board Games, Pen & Paper Games, Wargames, Card Games, Pen & Paper Board Card Games, whatever you want!My friends, to this day Continue to have a blast just sitting back and playing Games like Betrayal at House on the Hill, Pathfinder, or just screwing around and watching Youtube Videos on the tablet.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								A game where what you do can do things as though you and your friends were at an actual table playing whatever comes to mind, ranging from board games (such as Chess, Go, and Reversi), card games, to rpg role playing. All without the mess and streamlined actions for dealing and cleaning up cards. It even has gravity settings and blocks to play with.Further possibilities are added when you throw in board and deck importing into the mix. You're basically capable of playing any board game that exists as long as you or someone else knows how to make it. The possibilities are almost limitless, and this may even allow for new tabletop games to come to life, allowing for a potential whole new wave of board games.It can be a brilliant game for classic tabletop fun or for complete hilarity, allowing you to do things you wouldn't normally be able to do in your house, and even allowing you to do table flips. It's your choice.Probably one of the most simplistically innovative ideas for a game out there. I recommend it to the highest degree.Oh I almost forgot, make sure you have friends to play this with- you could always play online, but it's nothing like having you and a bunch of your friends at the same table messing around.

Posted: May 7, 2016
												Coming off the back of a long game of Battlestar Galactica, and trying to mod my own game into the system, if you are into board games or card games you can get some awesome times with this. The tech support from the devs is timely and on point, the game interface works (though because of what it does it is a bit clunky, even with scripting), and the community is generally friendly. Yes, it's mostly secret hitler if you look for games, but there's usually at least something else going, or playing with friends works most of the time (there are a few bugs probably courtesy of the overburdened interface).Still reecommended, this is the only software on steam I have purchased at full price, and have no regrets about that (though the sales are plentiful, I was just between them when I got it).

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
												Unlimited possibilities, and it ain't lying.  The only limit is your imagination.There is an absolute minimum amount of hand holding.  If you play Battleship, you will have to vocally call out the attack, and respond with hit or miss.  You have to drag the little piece to the board to fill out the grid yourself.  If you play poker, you actually have to deal the cards and count the chips.  In Jumanji, you're responsible for releasing your own wild animals (0/10).  That's really my only gripe, some workshop maps offer some scripting, but I'd like to see a bit more hand holding (like an auto dealer for hold'em, a chip counter for gambling, persistent servers, some self moving pieces).  You can cheat, you can flip the table, you can rage flick your buddies piece, and you can even play board games.  Highly recommended.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Tabletop simulator is an interesting "Game" if you can call it that, it's very different from any other game in that it's up to the players to come up with their own rules for play. Tabletop simulator is a board game simulation program that lets people play board games you would normally play in the same room across the internet. The game provides a decent amount of premade games and pieces to use with the steam workshop also supplementing this with custom models and game pieces. Essentially the game is very basic at it's core but is loose enough in it's functions that allows a very wide range of things you can do.I would of liked to see a few more features such as more board options and better drawing tools but it can be overlooked as they still update the game infrequently.I would also recommend having a few friends to play with as it's kind of the whole point of the game, I wouldn't recommend the game if you plan on playing alone or are uncomfortable playing with random players.Overall I'd say this is a great engine for creativity that could potentially provide endless hours of content if you can come up with the games to play or use the ones on the workshop.

Posted: September 13, 2015
												As of the time I write this review, I've only started to play around with this.  I'm a big RPG player, and a big fan of yugioh.  Both of these things are available, in spades, on the Steam Workshop.  Now, as soon as I can rope some of my friends into getting this game, we will be set for some awesome times XDMost of the controls are really convenient (WASD panning, solid mouse controls, etc), though I find the menus a bit difficult to navigate at times.  This game already has everything you need for a poker night, or any other traditional card game, built in, and has some basics for tabletop RPG's, as well.  Although the vanilla RPG resources are a touch scarce, they are plentiful on the Workshop, as intended.Better than expected physics, and definitely convenient, it has a lot of potential.

content:
Posted: January 13, 2016
												I'm honestly not sure if I can recommend this game as the real fun mostly comes from the Mods - and more importantly - the (original) board version of the mod.  You wouldn't rate a game sequel 10/10 if they did just the same thing again without any innovation.HOWEVER, Tabletop Simulator does a fantastic job allowing players to use their own game and offers a great opportunity to play board games with friends far away or even complete strangers. I don't play board games with the friends living close to me, so it's a great that I can simply join a online lobby and get a 8 player game starting in minutes!Playing more uncommon (but soooo good!) games like "Cards against Humanity" or "Secret Hitler" is a lot of fun, which wouldn't be possible (for me) without Tabletop Simulator. If you are in a similar situation as me, I can recommend getting TTS - but please do mind that a lot of fun is coming from the original creators of their respective board games and they should enjoy your support the same way!

content:
Posted: July 31, 2016
												It's time we forget about all the "monopoly online 2015 free" games on our tablets and phones. Here comes the Tabletop Simulator, the ultimate tool for having fun. You've always wanted to play some board games with someone you don't see really often? TTS will help. TTS provides the best experience out there, it doesn't "hold your hand" - rules are enforced by players, not the game itself. As a master (if the game needs one), you can always do some miscalculations - just like the real board game. No automatic stuff (unless it's scripted, it's possible, but not necessary).The game feels great. I've been waiting for a game like this for a couple of years, and finally it's here.Final score: 10/10.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 10, 2016
												I don't know why I didn't write a review for this game sooner, but after 200+ hours here it goes.In short: This game is amazing. It allows me to play board games with my friends all across the world. Not only that, but it also lets me try new games that I would have never had the gumption to go out and buy. Sometimes I've played games and it's been okay, other times I've played the game and immediately went to amazon to buy the physical copy.I first encountered the game in 2014 and after watching the video just didn't understand the potential. It seemed like one of many physics simulators and didn't seem to have much use beyond messing around and flipping tables.  Boy was I wrong. Since then, I've bought 8 copies of this game for me and my friends (because I'm a pushy board gamer that wants to play and they were hesitant to try). We have all greatly enjoyed the interface while not perfect, is incredibly funcitonal.The developers are also second to none. They are constantly releasing updates that greatly increases the functionality of the game. When they added scripting it basically made it a new game, greatly increasing the functionality of what the users could mod. Now they've added custom states and the ability to import unity asset bundles.This is no longer just a tabletop simulator, this is now a full fleged tabletop engine that offers an insane amount of freedom to board game developers. Not only does it help bring people together to play games at a distance, it also allows those interested in board game design to create prototypes without pilfering games for tokens.In the end... Awesome game. If you play board games or are even remotely interested, buy this. Don't even think about it, just click buy.

content:
Posted: July 16, 2014
												Have you ever wanted to play those card games from your youth such as Uno and the pokers without leaving the comfort of your computer? Of course not, you're twelve and don't know what an Uno is. But, for those of you who aren't twelve and know what an Uno is, this game is probably for you. Want to play Uno with cards that have Nicolas Cage's face on them? You got it. Eels and Escalators? Sure! A digital version of Space Hulk that isn't completely disappointing? Well, I'm not really a pen-and-paper kinda guy but who knows? Games and gaming objects for any occasion and necessity are available to you, the tabletop-but-not-on-an-actual-tabletop gaming public. "But, Mr. Speedchunk. I don't see the game I want/I have this idea for a game, what do?"Firstly, you don't start a sentence with "but". Secondly, if you don't see something you like, you can make it yourself.  The customization is flexible enough to be part of Cirque Du Soleil probably.You can even flip the table if you feel the rage overcome you. So if you have friends and want to simulate some tables, go ahead and play this game.

content:
Posted: May 7, 2016
												Coming off the back of a long game of Battlestar Galactica, and trying to mod my own game into the system, if you are into board games or card games you can get some awesome times with this. The tech support from the devs is timely and on point, the game interface works (though because of what it does it is a bit clunky, even with scripting), and the community is generally friendly. Yes, it's mostly secret hitler if you look for games, but there's usually at least something else going, or playing with friends works most of the time (there are a few bugs probably courtesy of the overburdened interface).Still reecommended, this is the only software on steam I have purchased at full price, and have no regrets about that (though the sales are plentiful, I was just between them when I got it).

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6, 2016
												100/10 IGNThe first thing I would like to say is that I have over one thousand hours on this game. Each, and every single hour was played. Not a single time did I start the game and just leave it on. That is a small way to sum up how much I truly adore this game. If you dislike tabletop games, then this is not for you. Do not buy this game just to flip tables or dismantle other people's games, because theres an easy banning system which can stop people within seconds. You're not even permenantly disrupting the game, because of the rewind feature. If you actually enjoy tabletop games, whether it's Cards Against Humanity, RPG's, or King of New York, then this is for you. It takes a bit to get used to all the controls, but after your first hour or so you'll have everything down if you went through the tutorial. This game is limitless in it's possabilities. I could litterally play almost any game, even if it's not actually a board game. Someone made a 100% Orange Juice replica in this, which is a great video game. The overall community is great, and eventually you will make friends from this game whether you like it or not. You'll come across people who enjoy the same games as you, and that's something I've yet to experience from any other game. Something that can sit me down and allow me to find someone with similar interests.

content:
Posted: August 5, 2016
												Tabletop Simulator (TTS) is exactly what it sounds like. It is a program that allows you to play pretty much any "analogue" game that you can think of, on the computer. While it will never replace the tactile feel that you get from holding actual game pieces or cards, nor the joy of sitting at a table with a bunch of other people who enjoy the game you are playing, it has so many benefits that any fan of any table top game needs to own this.First, you can theoretically play literally any tabletop game that exists in real life, on TTS. The mod community has shown a lot of hard work and creativity when it comes to available games on this. Aside from the standard games like Chess that already come with this game, you can play popular board games like the very popular, but much maligned Monopoly, to board game fan classic Battlestar Galactica. Even miniature games like Warhammer and Guild Ball are available to play. Want to play a LCG like Netrunner or Doomtown, but don’t want to shell out the hundreds of dollar’s worth of card expansions? It’s here too. If you have an idea for your own game, you can make it here too. The best part however, is it allows you to play these games at any time, even if your friends live far away, or if none of them are available. There is a community out there who wants to play these games. If you like table top games at all, and wish you could play them more often: get this game.9/10 “Excellent”

content:
Posted: November 11, 2016
												TL;DR: 11/10 +1 bonus point for workshop having everything you could ever want.This game is absolutely amazing if you spend the time to learn how to make it work. Any game you could possibly want (that can be played on a table top). It has a pretty healthy community of people so if you play often enough you'll start to get to know the different people. Want to learn to play MTG, D&D, Settlers of Catan and many more? just sit down at the table and ask you'd be surprised how many people are friendly and teach you how to play. the only problems is that there is a case of lag if everyone isnt in the same part of the world but it doesn't matter too much because the games can still be played easily. The game goes on sale pretty often but for the $20 price tag its absolutely worth it!
