content:
Posted: July 9, 2016
 If you enjoy board games and have friends to play with, I strongly recommend Tabletop Simulator for everyone. ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~+++  Timeless game with infinite board gaming potential +++ Makes you able to play board games with friends living anywhere in the world+++ Great number of workshop mods available++ You are able to create your own game or port an existing one++ Satisfying interaction with pieces and board++ Supports automation via scripting++ Only the host needs to buy the DLC content for all players to be able to play it+ Good physics+ VR Support- Official DLC prices seems a tad bit expensive comparing with the content you can get for free- You need a fixed group of friends who also own this game to play most of the content-- Very heavy load on your computer's RAM, definitely needs more optimization---  A wide variety of bugs, connection failures and crashes (at the time of this review) that can be very frustrating ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

content:
Posted: April 20, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game fits any persons desire to play board games and card games.  It comes highly reccomended, but you must realize thtat right now it is still in Early Access and the game has many flaws.  Some of which right now include occasional hard lag spikes, limited boards, and RPG options. However, it has come very apparent that Berserk games is very hell bent on making this work, so I would not be scared of this turning into a no full release early access game like many in this genre.Tabletop Simulator is wonderful in so many ways.  If your like me, Board Games are super fun but harder to get people to come around a table just to play them.  Tabletop Simulator is full of people from all sorts of places ready to play a simple universal game like checkers and chess.  What I love the most is the RPG options, although limited, are still in the game.  I always wanted to DnD, so this makes it easier to get into it without having to buy a bunch of peices. They do plan on expanding these options as well as many more.Finally, the biggest apeal to Tabletop Simulator is the costumization features.  People are playing ONLINE games of Uno, Monoply, and the very popular Cards Against Humanity in mere seconds.  I have also found people making their own boards or making their own games with the features in the game and playing their own wacky crap online.Overall, Tabletop Simulator comes highly reccomended to anyone.  The creativity is flowing more and more everyday from the users, and the game has only just begun.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								Digital will never beat the analogue. But digital might as well be the next analogue, if Berserk Games, creators of this masterpiece are considered.While other games are basically limiting players by enforcing rule designs, Tabletop Simulator let the players choose their game and how do they want to play it. If you want to play chess or any other of 15 classic games in Tabletop Simulator, be sure to know the rules because game will certainly not tell you how to play it. The only fences out there are your own knowledge, attention to playset and ability and willingness to cheat.Sandbox nature also bring psysics, so there are no more moves you cannot do. You even have the ability to smash the pieces and flip the table if you're angry and aggressive enough.But the biggest win, as younger generations might say, are the unlimited possibilities of modding - Steam Workshop is already full of mods of licensed games that play and look better than real licensed digital products. Someone might ask how much time until copyright owners decide to threaten Valve to pull a plug on these beautiful, user created mods, but even if it happens - Tabletop Simulator doesn't breach anyone's copyright and mods will certainly be available and easy accesible to everyone elsewhere.Finally, card and board games went digital and the pure enjoyment of meeting up with your friends and having a good time is certainly appreciated, especially by older generation of gamers whose free time and living spaces are getting more narrow as adulthood, family and children are coming by.DEFINITE RECOMMENDATION. Love yourself and get Tabletop Simulator.P.S. And a headset. You'll need one to laugh at other people. :)

content:
Posted: February 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								Ok first of this game suffers from a bad advertising video.I had seen this game come by a number of times in my reccomended list and everytime i clicked and watched the video i though it was just a dumb physics game like amputea or similar (just randomly throwing♥♥♥♥♥♥around on a table) no thanks.IT'S NOT!!! and i've been kicking myself that i hadn't bought this game earlier.It is in fact every board/card game you can think of just have a look at the workshop you'll find fully playable magic the gathering sets, warhammer, monopoly,uno,cards against humanity and original player created games.This game is amazing I have played a great number of new board games online with complete strangers and had a blast.I have had full mtg nights with my friends and 2 of the games that i never played before i actually bought the orriginal game so i can play it on game night with my friends on a real table instead of a virtual one.So it is also a great way to just try that really expensive board game you and your friends have been contemplating to buy in real life.So bassically when you buy this game you essentially buy 100's if not 1000's of new games all in one If you like boardgames/card games/role playing games or just if you just like games in general you should own this game don't even wait for it to go on sale it's worth the full price.But don't believe anything i say just ahve a look on youtube for tabletop simulator for some good videos on how this game should be used (the devs might learn a thing or 2 about promoting their own game)

Posted: July 2, 2016
												Alright, this game is popular many others have already nailed down why this game is so good(Massive replayability, large community, etc.) However, many have neglected some important things that suck about this game:  -Singleplayer exists; in a fashion: You can explore a table by yourself, but there are NO BOTS or any form of AI. Exploring a tabletop by yourself is just a preview more so than anything else. There are puzzles like Tower of Hanoi that can accomdate a single player, one can tell from booting the game up its made for multiplayer. Unless you have friends who'll buy this game, I recommend you stay away, as right now the community can be toxic(I write this as of the Steam Summer Sale, so after a few weeks the community will stablize, no worries.) -Local play is rather complicated. content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
Early Access Review
								I must be honest my hopes were far too high prior to purchasing this game, and realising that the table is dangling in the air sort of ruined it initially. Yet i persevered, and came to really enjoy playing the game.It must be said that there is limited enjoyibility to be had when  playing single, but as long as you've got at least one obedient friend to join you either online or hot-seat then you're set to enjoy a quick game of chess... or monopoly!The workshop is probably one of the greatest features, every board game of your childhood can be witnessed, played, and then flipped when you inevitably lose. Yet with the "undo button", i'm sure the opponent won't mind too much.To summarise, a game with really fun physics, a crazy idea, and a well populated workshop. Well worth a buy both in or out of a sale... Word of advice however, try to ensure at least one friend buys it too, online games are sooooo much more fun than sharing the computer/laptop/rock.9.5/10 Dice rolled

content:
Posted: August 2, 2015
												A very robust engine for letting you play tabletop games with your friends online.A review for this game is not especially helpful as I can only really review the engine itself, and whether or not you have fun comes down to if you can use the program in the right way.  A game played in Tabletop Simulator is only as good as the mod creator made it to be.  A TRPG is only going to be as fun as the people you play with.  That's just how it works.Your first step should be to look at the Steam Workshop for a few games you might be looking to play with your friends, or think about which you might want to work on yourself.  I myself added a mod to the workshop for a now-defunct CCG, and it wasn't too hard.  Adding some resources for modding could be an important improvement from the devs, but with a little elbow grease, reddit / steam forum searching, and google you can find the answers you need without difficulty.If you've got some tabletop games you want to play online, this is the tool for you.  Still receives regular updates too.

content:
Posted: May 12, 2016
												After playing over a hundred hours in this game, I think I can finally create a good, unbiased opinion on this game. As a disclaimer, I originally bought this game back in early 2015, a few months before it left Early Access. Throughout this time, I have seen many changes to the game. Both good and bad. The BadI'll be starting off with the bad stuff. The biggest complaint I have against the game, is the lack of variety. This has been a thing ever since I bought it, but it has become more obvious as time goes on. Most of the games currently are Blackjack or Poker, Secret Hitler, and MTG. While these games aren't bad, and it is certainly easy to startup your own game, it's also a bit depressing to see these games as the only ones that are commonly open, with the more rare games quickly getting filled up. That said, you do have some other games such as Codenames or X-Wings, that are more rare, but luckily pop up a lot.Another issue I have with the game, is the weird loading bugs that still occur today. These bugs may range from anything to your game refusing to load certain files and forcing the loading symbol to stay on your screen, to the voice chat looping over and over, as the game loads in. While these aren't game breaking, they certainly are annoying.The GoodThe game has an amazingly large selection of games to play, and more than likely you'll learn about new games that you never heard of, or knew how to play. For example, I never knew what Betrayal at the House on the Hill was, but after playing TTS, it has become one of my favorite board games. Also, the community is generally laid back and friendly, meaning that you can easily get into a game and learn it without being mocked or belittled. Overall, the atmosphere of the game is very cozy, and you don't really feel unwelcome.The VerdictIf you like board games in the least, Tabletop Sim is probably one of the best games out there for that. Even though the game originally showed off the 'chaos' element to it, the game itself is much more than just that.

								Never in my life would i think something as simple as this would be so much fun, sure its a little weird getting used to for the first hour or 2, but when you get in or make a good game of blackjack, Chutes and Ladders, Uno or BS with a bunch of friendly people you don't know, it becomes real fun and sad when the game is over and you have to go. Purple Hitler dumps Liberal, adds Facist, says no choice.  Yellow backs up the triple Facist claim.  Purple instantly identifies a Facist.Eventually, Green and Blue are caught in a conflict, with people pointing at Blue (later inspected by Green, claimed Liberal).  Poor Blue later gets shot.  Purple Hitler was one of the voices leading to this shot.Purple Hitler is selected again for Chancellor with a chance to win.  Downvoted due to Liberal strategy trying to get a certain President.  Later, Purple becomes President with 5 Facist out.  Selects someone he thinks is Liberal.  Vote gets approved.  Draws 3 Facist cards.  Shows them on table confirming sixth will come to win regaardless, then shows Hitler card to shock and amazement.Purple was me.10/10 would lie again.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 23
												While I do have a serious problem with the fact that you are not supporting the company by playing it through tabletop simulator I will say it is a great game.Pro- One of the Easiest ways to play games with friends period. If many of your friends live quite a distance from you this is a very easy way to stay in touch and have fun at the same time!- Many people in the community make their own games, many tools are supported to be able to do this and almost nothing limits the creatiability.- The community is usually very friendly. Yes theres always that one guy who likes to come around all the time but it is mostly fine. People are almost always ok with teaching you new games and are ok with being patient as you learn the controls.Cons- The controls can be difficult to learn as a newer player, ive played for almost 1,400 hours at this point and i still do not know some of them to be honest.- Again as i said before i think there should be a better way to support the actual creators. There is some DLC that you can purchase for some games namely Cosmic Encounter which as far as i know does go back a little to the company.Overall i would reccomend this product though it can be a little annoying to newer players to get used to.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 4
												My review will concentrate on 3 areas:1) The simulator itself, and provided (free) and pay content - In a word, delightful. An easy interface, and the ability to connect and play with friends the world over is really cool. Great visuals, and of course the sandbox nature encourages a lot of DIY. For $20, it's hard to beat the value of this app, especially if you are a fan of games that require thought, strategy, and a human opponent to make them their most satisfying and entertaining.2) Out-of-print, rare, old games - The potential for bringing back many out-of-print, never-to-be reprinted games (old SPI, Avalon Hill, etc.) is pretty great, especially with the prices some people are asking for copies on eBay. I understand that someone, somewhere has the "rights" to these titles, but as long as they are not using them. I fully intend to try to digitize at least one of my favorites, or at least assist others in creating more content, particularly in the area of wargames.  VASSAL is also great for many of these, but take a hybrid card/counter/hex map/character sheet/encounter book game like the great WW2 infantry solitaire title, Ambush! - the VASSAL interface just isn't made for it. But I think TTS might just fit the bill.3) Existing, in print, readily available modern games. As many reviewers have stated, it's an uneasy feeling. As a musician, I've seen the changes in the recording industry over the past two decades, and how difficult i(nearly impossible) it is to make a living as a recording artist these days. For the consumer, it's the problem of too many great games, too little time and money. My hope is that publishers are looking at what's going on here and hoping that the chance to experience their products on TTS will drive physical sales, and I will admit - I've bought a ton of X-Wing stuff, although that was largely driven by the fact of playing on VASSAL (where you need the pilot cards, secondary weapon/mod cards, damage decks, etc.) in order to play. But as I learn to play on VASSAL and on TTS, it does increase my desire to play face-to-face with friends and family, and that has also contributed to my acquiring physical expansions. I also know that at the moment, I am concentrating much of my TTS time on X-Wing, even though I have subscribed to MANY other games.In closing, you should come play. It's a lot of fun!

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Tabletop Simulator brings the joy and fun of playing a tabletop board game with your friends without the hassle of pregame setup, postgame cleanup, and setting up everyone's schedules. Not only does it have a ton of games out of the box, with more virtual downloadable board games, there are tons of community workshop mods for your old favourites. If you don't find what you are looking for, you can make it yourself with a host of creation and custom tools. Probably the best part about Tabletop Simulator is the fact that you can try out a virtual version of a board game if you're iffy about purchasing it. If you like it, great, go support the developers! If not, try out something different.I definitely reccomend Tabletop Simulator.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2016
												Ive owned this game for a while but havent gotten into it before. I jumped in to this wanting to play texas holdem and then I got introduced to some tabletop games via other players at first through texas holdem. One of the blackjack tables is very fun with power ups, silly and cool rewards and fun people. Secret hitler is also an interesting table top game, where you have to try and figure out who is a fascist and who is hitler. People will lie and will try to convince you that they are your friend and then stab you in the back if they succeed. I havent had much time with the others, but I think that you can play all table top games in the universe, in this game. With firsthand experience of the fun, and with the knowledge of VR support I can see that this game has a very, very bright present and future. It does not deserve less than 10/10. Its just really really good. And if it doesnt stick at first, give it a go now and again and Im certain you will enjoy it.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												Tabletop Simulator is the kind of game you are either going to play once for an hour with some friends, or spend hundreds of hours with your friends playing a variety of board games. The community support behind this game is excellent, and there's is a massive host of games that you can get. Quite the excellent purchase, not only economically ($20 CAD or $10 on sale) but it also provides a unique experience for those of us who can't get together in person to play board games. The automatic scripting that some of the mod creators have put into their games can often times save loads of preparation time,  while enhancing the games themsleves by automatics many tiresome features. This game is definately worth the purchase if you have friends to play with on a somewhat regular basis.

												Tabeltop Simulator by itself is a barebones user interface that gives you a digital space to play tabletop games: A table, a background, game pieces, and simple UI tools to manipulate game pieces.Where Tabletop Simulator shines is the Steam Workshop Community.  In fact, I would say the longevity of this software/game entirely is dependant on the efforts of the community.  The active community is always creating new game assets and digitizing popular board games.This game is really the best way to connect with friends who cannot get together physically to play board games or role playing games.

content:
Posted: February 12, 2016
												Great platform for organizing tabletop games with people across the world, what you can do is pretty much only limited by your creativity and imagination. Adding your own art and objects is not the most straightforward though, as it requires you to upload it somewhere online first, but is not too difficult and allows for easy distribution to all players.Drawing on the table allows for taking quick notes, but of course will mainly be used to sketch crude pictures of♥♥♥♥♥♥♥At first it's easy to do simple mistakes with the objects such as dragging the whole deck instead of one card, but after a while the mechanics are pretty simple and flexible. Would recommend.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 15, 2016
												Have you played Monopoly? It's here. Mafia? It's here. Settlers of Catan? You guessed it. WARHAMMER 40 FREAKIN' K?!? We've got you covered! I can guarantee you will find any table top games you may have played irl*.*With the small exception of small, local and obscure games****Even though I've seen such in the Workshop.Buy this. Why? Because it's cheaper than ANY tabletop game. And you get ALL OF THEM. Of course, you're limited to the imagination of others who upload (not necessarily) their creations. All you need to do is subscribe to the collections (games) you need so that you may host them.The community. It's great. I've made so many new acquaintances I enjoy playing a sesh of any game you can think of.The value. Enormous. Good example - I've always wanted to start playing Warhammer 40k however due to financial reasons (and living in a second world country) and crippling debt, I was never able to order and/or play Warhammer 40k with anyone irl. Not that anyone here has any models. ANYHOW, back to my point - you can literally almost always find a Warhammer 40K game hosted here. It's like a dream come true!The reasons. Plenty. You will make new acquaintances, you will play games, both old and new, you will have FUN.The learning curve. Anything but steep. It took me approximately three days (not 72 hours in total) but rather three days of playing every now and then a game or two to learn most of the controls and key bindings to make the most of my gaming.My thought on the game? Initially I was skeptical. The price seemed expensive, but let me tell you. Deciding to buy this during the Lunar Festival sale might have been the best decision I've made while I have been on Steam. This is probably my favourite game now. I'm not even overestimating. This is it.If I have to rate my experience, I'd go with 9/10. Why? Because despite the variety of the game, there are always small bits and bobs that can be improved, or games and models can be imported with more HD values, but these are all minor inconveniences and should not impact your decision whether to buy the game or not.Get this. GET THIS. WHY ARE YOU STILL READING THIS REVIEW!?

												Worth every penny. The amount of board games available from the community is amazing to the point where it is almost impossible to measure the amount of value this game has. One board game from a local book store would run you, on average, $40. For one $20 purchase on Steam (I paid $10 when this was on sale) you can have access to thousands of board games. content:
Posted: February 23
												C'mon, you can flip the table when you win!  Or lose!The beauty of this game is that, in a nutshell, you're given all the bits and then you play with little to no guidance beyond basic controls.  You either play the game right, play the game wrong, or you throw around a bowl full of dominoes and play bowling with oversized chess pieces while "Through The Fire and Flames" is blaring on a virtual iPad.  I don't think there's any better way of playing board games online.

content:
Posted: March 19
												This game is fantastic.  I love being able to have a game night with my old buddies even when we can't all get together to do it.  If the game doesn't have it, odds are the extensive collection of mods holds what you seek.  That being said, the game does seem to be pretty demanding on the system, so be prepared for some lag if you don't have the best gaming rig.  Another issue I recently encountered was that the audio from the server host I was playing with the other day was quite choppy, likely due to his computer trying to balance hosting with chatting at the same time, but hey, that's more than likely the fault of his system and not of the game.  Overall, I give Tabletop Simulator an 8/10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								GREAT GAMEThis game gives you unlimited freedom to play by the rules or to just have fun!  Ever wondered what to do with that Backgammon game nobody know how to play?  Learn the rules elsewhere... or just play with the pieces!  Gotten angry to the point where you would rather flip the table than talk it over?  Flip the table!  Have a creative idea for the next big board/card game since Monopoly?  Go for it!  This game's got your back when it comes to doing anything you want and having a great time.Pros:No computer-based limitationsVery creativeMultiplayerAnybody can playEasy-to-use interface for server adminsTotal freedomGreat graphicsCons:Could be cheaper (about $5 or $10?)Most servers require passwords to joinNo Steam Workshop (yet)Limited amount of pieces to use (it's plenty, though)A lot of keys to memorizeVerdict: 8.8/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								After playing a small amount of this game, I am already convinced that this is going to be big. Pretty much any game is possible as long as it's not got a large 3d board. Games such as Carcassonne are not currently possible but will be upon the addition of custom block shapes and designs. For a game that is early access, it has a lot of functionality and will improve with mods and work from developers. Don't expect multiplayer to be civilised without friends of your own to play with, you might find a few but for every person who wants to play properly there are two who don't understand the game and flip the table for lulz.Get it.(ノಠ益ಠ)ノ彡┻━┻

content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								Great Simulator for an Actual Tabletop. It lets you play Boardgames and other Tabletop games online with other people, without taking up the space required by traditional boardgames and the need to meet in person. It comes with some classic board games by default, but you can download and host some other board games on the workshop, or even make your own. Its a lot of fun, there is some potential for griefing, but if you're the game's host you can turn some of those features off so that you can play your games through without a problem. If you like boardgame pick this up, if your friends have it pick it up. If you don't like board games and don't have friends to play with, I wouldn't reccomend it though.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2015
												Tabletop Sim makes it possible to play virtually any board game over the internet...properaly. It comes preset with some classics (Chess, Checkers etc), along with lots of objects you may use for other board games (dice, various tokens, even monsters that actually move if you want to setup a role-playing game), as well as the tools to creating your own board game. Having Steam Workshop makes this game have endless replayibility, where you can download and play virtually any card/board game you can think of (Munchkins is really popular on here). Although most of these mods are copyrighted, and they have a chance to be removed. Tabletop Sim has straightforward UI, with a very quick tutorial to get you used to basic controls. Hosting a game is extremely easy, and it's very stable as long as you don't load up too many objects. Go for it. ...and I thank the devs for supporting Linux :D

This is really when you're bored, you have nothing else to do, and you got time to waste on, this is the game for you. For others to play, they need a steam account I think, and just buy the game. I love flipping the table over, of course. This is the ultimate sandbox game I've ever seen on Steam, beside Valve's "Garry's Mod." I wish there were more of these games that are on Steam...

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								I was interested when I first heard of this game back when it was on Kickstarter. I regret not getting the game earlier then and helping the developers out with my money.Since getting this game I've had fun playing tabletop games with friends whom I don't get to see in person as often.On top of a bunch of classical games (Chess, checkers, etc) the modding community for this game is HUGE, allowing many games to be created or imported (Cards Against Humanity, Monopoly, MTG, etc, etc, etc, etc).While this game is still (as of the time of writing this) in an early access phase there aren't many bugs or errors you'd expect in some other early access games. The worst bug you can expect is random crashes, but those are few and far between (in some cases it is the mod's fault and not the game's, such as having very large file sizes that wrecks your computer).All that being said, I highly recommend this game and would like to commend the developers for delivering a great product. I cannot wait to see what else can be added / refined as this game grows.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 31, 2015
Early Access Review
								Like board games? Card Games? Minatures games? pen and paper RPGs? Then you'll like this! It does exactly what it says on the tin. Hundreds of mods on the workshop to replicate anything from long-dead CCGs to modern board games. There are a few rough edges owing to it being in early access, but so far this seems to be one of the good ones. It plays perfectly well, just has a few finnicky little things here and there (exiting the program by closing the window always results in an error message, for example). But it's perfectly stable while you're playing.

												Tabeltop Simulator by itself is a barebones user interface that gives you a digital space to play tabletop games: A table, a background, game pieces, and simple UI tools to manipulate game pieces.Where Tabletop Simulator shines is the Steam Workshop Community.  In fact, I would say the longevity of this software/game entirely is dependant on the efforts of the community.  The active community is always creating new game assets and digitizing popular board games.This game is really the best way to connect with friends who cannot get together physically to play board games or role playing games.

content:
Posted: October 24, 2015
												Tabletop Simulator is one of those sucessful Kickstarter campaigns. It's a great game, even if you could call it a game, it's more of a tool in which you can play board games, people are porting real life board games into the steam workshop, and even making their own games especifically for tabletop sim. There's a lot of playtime here, even though my hours with the game can't prove it, i would strongly reccomend you get some friends to play this game with you. you'll probably waste more time with friends than with strangers. Also, DLC, Right as the time of this review there are only 2 DLC(SuperFight and Cosmic Encounters) which for people to play, need to also buy the especific dlc. but you can also pay for a more expensive version of the dlc but it let's you play with anyone that doesn't have the dlc. at the end this is a great game, i've been playing it since it was on early access and i can say that it is a must have if you want a game to play with friends.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 14, 2015
												Its 20$ regularly, and about 12$ or so on sale, for infinite tabletop possibilities, from monopoly to warhammer and magic the gathering, as well as the ability to make your own games and play them online with friends and faimly. Not only is this a great deal, its on a great physics engine with hundreds of features and the dev's are always out to improve; the game gets better and better constantly. Its litterally infinite games within a game. The 3d graphics are smooth and enjoyable, there are so many small things you can do that make this game a masterpeice. The mod community is great, and the deal here is amazing, 10/10, worth every penny. The only downfall the game is that there isnt a very extensive community for playing games, it seems like you have to wait a little to long to start a game of anything other than secret hitler or cards against humanity. Reguardless of this, its still a much easier way to play games with freinds and family at any given time on the go.

												A must buy for any board game fan. And especially for those people who always thought board games looked like fun, but it just wasn't convenient enough for their 21st century selves. Either way, you'll be happy you bought it. It is an absolute blast playing a game previously only played irl. Many said games can be obtained from the Steam Workshop, which imo is one of the best decisions the devs made. My son and I played a game of Axis&Allies 1941 Anniversary Edition and it was some of the most fun I've had in a game in a while. It was in the workshop along with many other great board games. So basically, you can have any game you've ever wanted but couldn't get because they are approximately 80 dollars each. 1. Purchase Tabletop Simulator2. Download for free ridiculously priced board games3. Destroy your friends

content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								Tabletop Simulator is a wonderful tool that allows you to play a massive range of board, card, and dice games, whether they're from the Steam Workshop or built into the software. The controls are simple and easy to learn and almost never feel finnicky, there are a huge variety of pieces and items that are included in the software to create your own games and more with, and with options for online and hotseat multiplayer, playing with friends is incredibly easy. If you can think of it and it can be played on a table, you can probably make it in this game. My only problems so far are stacking cards (you need to be quite precise) and dropping counters into exact places (sometimes, the piece falls at an odd angle, even if the cursor is still and the camera facing straight down). Despite being in early access, this tool is well worth a buy.PROS:+Huge amount of games on the Workshop, as well as built into the software itself, meaning there's a huge variety of games available.+Simple to use, easy to learn.+You can make your own games.+You can flip the table.CONS:-Some issues with precise placement/stacking cards onto a deck.-Requires multiple people to get the full benefit of the game.

content:
Posted: July 12, 2016
												This is probably among my most satisfied steam purchases I've ever made. It's not so much a game as a simulator used to play a bunch of other games. It's basically a physics simulator built around board games, but also has alot of great modding tools, which has resulted in pretty much every board game or card game you've ever played being recreated by fans in a digital format. I don't think it's possible to ever run out of fun stuff to do in this program. Lots of good tools for multiplayer but I've had quite a bit of fun in single player as well. Frankly, my only complaint is that more of my friends aren't already using it.

												Awesome game, well put together and just plain all the more great with how much sheer content has been published by people willing to provide it in the workshop. This game is simply great if you even remotely enjoy board games, card games, tabletop pen and paper games (such as DnD, pathfinder, and so on) and even random yelling at your friends for flipping the table 50 too many times after you have had to reset it for the last hour of idiocy at its finest.But really though, with how well all of this is put together, and the community 'mostly' being pleasant to teach a game never before learned is amazing, and makes it honestly worth the price tag.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 30, 2016
Product received for free
												Before I begin my review, I was gifted this by a friend.  That has no impact on my review however.Tabletop Simulator is exactly what the name implies.  It is a great way to play board, card, RPG tabletop, and other types of table games with your friends online.  There is no end to what you can play.  From Chess, checkers, Uno, Monopoly, party card games, pictionary, and so many others.  The controls are simplistic and easy to understand.  There is a short tutorial that will show you how to grab cards, use objects and figures, and roll dice.  A mouse and keyboard is all you need.  Graphics are also nice, although some different types of games can lag the program a bit.  Usually a refresh fixes that though.Overall, it is well worth the price I believe.  Even without the DLC you can find an endless number of games to play with friends.  As long as you enjoy tabletop games, you will thoroughly enjoy this one.

content:
Posted: August 15, 2016
												This game is exactly what it looks like, it allows to concievably play any possible table-based game.The controls are easy to manage, and things function as you'd expect them to, although sometimes the objects interact oddly.Note full enjoyment of the game requires you to use mods, because the base game only has a few games in it. Which is also its strength, since it can essentially have infinite games in its library if you include the mods.So if you like board games, and want to play them with your online friends, buy this game. And then convince them to buy it aswell.
